conclusion: A particle moves in a uniform electric field inside a cylinder with a circular cross-section. AB is a diameter, and point C is on the circumference such that angle θ between AC and AB is 60 degrees.
The particle has mass m and charge q (positive) and enters the electric field at point A with different velocities in the plane of the paper, perpendicular to the electric field.
If the particle enters with zero initial velocity, it exits the field at point C with speed v₀.
The particle is only subjected to the electric force during its motion.
The cross-section is a circle with center O. AB is a diameter, so B is directly opposite to A across the center.
Point C is on the circumference such that angle θ between AC and AB is 60 degrees.

premise: If AB is a diameter, then angle ACB is 90 degrees because angle in a semicircle is 90 degrees.
Angle θ is between AC and AB, which is at point A, so angle θ is angle CAB = 60 degrees.
In triangle ABC, angle ACB is 90 degrees and angle CAB is 60 degrees.

conclusion: The electric field is uniform within the cylindrical region, and the particle enters at point A with velocity perpendicular to the electric field.
When the particle enters with zero initial velocity, it exits the field at point C with speed v₀.
Since the particle is only subjected to the electric force, its motion will be uniform acceleration in the direction of the electric field.

premise: The particle starts at rest at point A and accelerates uniformly due to the electric field, exiting at point C with speed v₀.
In uniform acceleration, the final velocity v₀ is related to the acceleration a and the distance d by the equation v₀² = 2 a d.
The acceleration a is given by a = E q / m.
Combining v₀² = 2 a d and a = E q / m, we get v₀² = 2 (E q / m) d.
